title: Stefan Reuter
text:
Stefan Reuter (born 16 October 1966) is a German <a href="Association%20football">football</a> executive and former player who played as a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29">defender</a> or <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a>. He is the general manager of <a href="Bundesliga">Bundesliga</a> club <a href="FC%20Augsburg">FC Augsburg</a>.
During his playing career, he was a member of the <a href="West%20Germany%20national%20football%20team">West Germany national football team</a> squad which won the <a href="1990%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1990 FIFA World Cup</a> squad and the <a href="Germany%20national%20football%20team">Germany</a> squad which won <a href="UEFA%20Euro%201996">UEFA Euro 1996</a>. He also won the <a href="1996%E2%80%9397%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">1996–97 UEFA Champions League</a> with <a href="Borussia%20Dortmund">Borussia Dortmund</a>.
Club career.
Born in <a href="Dinkelsb%C3%BChl">Dinkelsbühl</a>, Reuter started his career with local side TSV 1860 Dinkelsbühl. In 1982, he played for <a href="1.%20FC%20N%C3%BCrnberg">1. FC Nürnberg</a>, first in the <a href="2.%20Bundesliga">2. Bundesliga</a> and, from 1985, in the Bundesliga. In exactly 100 games he scored ten goals. He was occasionally used as a <a href="Midfielder%23Winger">right sided midfielder</a>.
In 1988, he was transferred to <a href="FC%20Bayern%20Munich">Bayern Munich</a>. He played 95 games in the Bundesliga and scored four goals for the <a href="Bavaria">Bavaria</a>ns. He won the <a href="List%20of%20German%20football%20champions">Bundesliga title</a> with Bayern in <a href="1988%E2%80%9389%20Bundesliga">1988–89</a> and <a href="1989%E2%80%9390%20Bundesliga">1989–90</a>.
A proposed move to <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a> following West Germany's victorious World Cup campaign was turned down at the last minute with Reuter following many of his compatriots to Italy. From 1991 to 1992 he played for <a href="Juventus%20F.C.">Juventus</a>, but soon returned to Germany, joining <a href="Borussia%20Dortmund">Borussia Dortmund</a>. With Borussia, Reuter won the Bundesliga in <a href="1994%E2%80%9395%20Bundesliga">1994–95</a>, <a href="1995%E2%80%9396%20Bundesliga">1995–96</a> and <a href="2001%E2%80%9302%20Bundesliga">2001–02</a>, and the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a> in <a href="1996%E2%80%9397%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">1996–97</a>. The team also reached the final of the <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a> in both <a href="1992%E2%80%9393%20UEFA%20Cup">1993</a> and <a href="2002%20UEFA%20Cup%20Final">2002</a>. Overall, he played 307 games for Dortmund and scored 11 goals in the Bundesliga before retiring in 2004.
He also played for the German national team. All in all it were 69 games (two goals) for Nürnberg (nine), Bayern Munich (18), Juventus (18) and Borussia Dortmund (33).
International career.
In 1984, Reuter was part of the team that won the U-16 European Championship. He later won the <a href="1990%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1990 World Cup</a>, as well as the <a href="UEFA%20Euro%201996">Euro 1996</a>. At Euro 1996 he scored one of the penalties in the semi-final shootout against <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a>, however like <a href="Andreas%20M%C3%B6ller">Andreas Möller</a> he was suspended for the <a href="UEFA%20Euro%201996%20Final">final</a>.
In 1992, Reuter became the first player in the European Championship history to be substituted as a substitute, when during the match between Germany and Scotland, he replaced <a href="Karl-Heinz%20Riedle">Karl-Heinz Riedle</a> but then only seven minutes later he had to leave the field due to an injury, and was replaced by <a href="Michael%20Schulz">Michael Schulz</a>.
He was known for his speed on the field; as a sprinter in his youth he ran the 100 metres in 10.8 seconds, a quality that resulted in his nickname "Turbo".
Managing career.
Reuter served as team manager for <a href="TSV%201860%20M%C3%BCnchen">TSV 1860 München</a> from January 2006 to 2 February 2009 when he was removed from the job.
On 27 February 2012, he was appointed as general manager of <a href="FC%20Augsburg">FC Augsburg</a>.
